citation.article-title: Clostridium hathewayi sp. nov., from human faeces.

p.s: Description of Clostridium hathewayi sp. nov.

Clostridium hathewayi (ha.the.way.i N. L. gen. n. hathewayi of Hatheway, to honour the late American microbiologist Charles L Hatheway in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the Clostidium botulinum group of organisms)
Cells stain Gram-negative and consist of gram-type positive, endosporing rods.
Cells are 0.7–1.0 μm x 2.0–5.0 μm with pointed ends and occur in chains of up to 30 cells.
Spores were slightly oval to almost round, and sub-terminally located; sporulating cells were a little swollen.
Some cells form slime capsules.
May or may not be motile.
On Columbia sheep blood agar colonies are 2 to 3mm in diam. after 3 days, nonhemolytic, greyish-white, opaque, convex, round with a slightly irregular margin and shiny.
The temperature range for growth is 15 °C to 45 °C, with an optimum around 37 °C; pH range for growth is 5.0 to 8.5, with an optimum of around 7.0.
The doubling time under optimum conditions in PY medium was 50 mins.
Gowth occurs in 0 to 2.5% NaCl.
Strictly anaerobic.
Catalase negative.
Saccharolytic; acetate, ethanol, CO2 and H2 are the end products of glucose metabolism.

Acid is produced from amygdalin, arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, melibiose, melezitose, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose, salicin, sorbitol, starch, sucrose, trehalose and xylose.
Acid is not produced from glycogen, inositol, inulin or mannitol.
Esculin and starch are hydrolysed but cellulose, gelatin and urea are not hydrolysed.
Lecithinase and lipase negative.
Indol is not produced and nitrate is not reduced.
The DNA G+C content is 50.7 to 50.9 mol%.
Isolated from chemostat enrichment for phytic acid degrading bacteria.
Source: human faeces.
The type strain 1313T of Clostridium hathewayi has been deposited in the DSMZ as DSM 13479T (= CCUG 43506T).
Clostridium hathewayi is phylogenetically a member of the Clostridium coccoides group of organisms and displays a close phylogenetic affinity with Clostridium sphenoides and related species.
